title: Crime, Punishment, and Progress in Southern History, 1865 to present
yc_attrs:
This course can be applied towards the following Yale College distributional requirements:
  • Humanities and Arts
  • Writing
description: This seminar offers an introduction to the history of the American South through readings on the Jim Crow racial state and resistance to it. We explore the region’s past of extralegal violence, its embrace of formal policing, and its turn to mass incarceration. Temporally, we are concerned with the period between the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment and our contemporary movements for black (and blue) lives. Thematically, we engage with historical processes of gender and racial formation, white supremacist discipline, racial capitalism, and social mobilization. Topics include the convict lease, segregation, lynching, law enforcement, civil rights activism, Black Power, and carceral abolitionism. In addition to narratives of the domestic black freedom struggle, we expand the South to include colonial spaces, the border, and the Global South. Along the way we hone research and communication skills through the analysis of political, intellectual, and cultural sources from the archives. Our semester culminates in a work of original research.
